sentences.sentence: Then the snow came, and after the snow came the frost( 霜 ).
The streets looked as if they were made of bright and shining silver.
Long icicles hung down under the roofs( 屋顶 ) of the houses, and everybody wore warm coats.
The little boys wore red hats and skated on the ice.
The poor little Swallow( 燕子 ) grew colder and colder, but he would not leave the Prince( 王子 ), because he loved him too much.
He picked up pieces of bread outside the baker’s( 面包店 ) door when the baker( 面包师 ) was not looking,
and tried to keep himself warm by flapping( 拍打 ) his wings.
But at last he knew that he was going to die.
He had just enough strength to fly up to the Prince( 王子 )’s shoulder once more.
“Goodbye, dear Prince( 王子 )!” he said. “Will you let me kiss your hand?”
“I am glad that you are going to Egypt( 埃及，地名 ) at last, little Swallow( 燕子 ),” said the Prince( 王子 ).
“You have stayed too long here, but you must kiss me on the lips( 嘴唇 ), because I love you.”
“I am not going to Egypt( 埃及，地名 ),” said the Swallow( 燕子 ).
“I am going to die.
Death is the brother of Sleep, is he not?”
And he kissed the Happy Prince( 王子 ) on the lips( 嘴唇 ), and fell down dead at his feet.
At that moment a strange cracking( 爆裂声 ) sound came from inside the statue( 雕像 ), as if something had broken.
The fact is that the Prince( 王子 )’s iron heart had broken in two.
It certainly was a very cold day.
Early the next morning the Mayor( 市长 ) was walking in the city square, along with some of his colleagues( 同僚 ).
As they passed the column( 柱子 ), the Mayor( 市长 ) looked up at the statue( 雕像 ).
“Dear me! How bad the Happy Prince( 王子 ) looks today!” he said.
“Very bad, indeed!” agreed his colleagues( 同僚 ), who always agreed with the Mayor( 市长 ).
They all went up to get a closer look at it.
“The ruby( 红宝石 ) has fallen out of his sword( 宝剑 ), his eyes are gone, and he is no longer golden,” said the Mayor( 市长 ).
“He looks no better than a beggar( 乞丐 )!”
“No better than a beggar( 乞丐 ),” agreed his colleagues( 同僚 ).
“And there is even a dead bird at his feet!” continued the Mayor( 市长 ).
“We must really make a public announcement( 公告 ) that birds are not allowed to die here.”
And his colleagues( 同僚 ) all wrote a note about the Mayor( 市长 )’s suggestion.
So they pulled down the statue( 雕像 ) of the Happy Prince( 王子 ).
“He is no longer beautiful, so he is neither beautiful nor useful,” the Mayor( 市长 ) announced( 宣布 ) to the public.
After the Mayor( 市长 ) had spoken, they melted down( 熔化 ) the statue( 雕像 ),
and a public meeting was held to decide what was to be done with the metal( 金属 ).
“We must build another statue( 雕像 ), of course,” said the Mayor( 市长 ), “and it will be a statue( 雕像 ) of myself.”
“Of myself,” said each of his colleagues( 同僚 ), and they argued.
When they were last heard of, they were still arguing.
“What a strange thing!” said the worker who melted down( 熔化 ) the statue( 雕像 ).
“This broken iron heart will not melt( 熔化 ).
We must throw it away.”
So he threw it onto a trash( 垃圾 ) pile( 堆 ), where the dead Swallow( 燕子 ) was also lying.
But this was not the end of the story.
The Angels( 天使 ) had seen everything.
They had watched the Happy Prince( 王子 ) and the Swallow( 燕子 ).
They had seen the good that they had done.
And that is why when God said to one of his Angels( 天使 ), “Bring me the two most precious( 珍贵的 ) things in the city.”
The Angel( 天使 ) brought Him the iron heart and the dead bird.
“You have chosen correctly,” said God.
“In my garden of Paradise( 天国 ), this little bird will sing until the end of time,
and in my city of gold, the Happy Prince( 王子 ) will praise me.”
